title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
description: A novel set in the American South during the 1930s, dealing with the issues of racial injustice and moral growth.

author: George Orwell
description: A dystopian novel about a totalitarian regime, surveillance, and the loss of individual freedom.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
description: A novel set in the Roaring Twenties, exploring themes of decadence, idealism, resistance to change, social upheaval, and excess.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
description: A romantic novel following the life of Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates issues of manners, morality, education, and marriage in early 19th-century England.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
description: A novel about a teenager's existential crisis, dealing with themes of innocence, identity, belonging, loss, and connection.

title: To the Lighthouse
author: Virginia Woolf
description: A modernist novel exploring themes of time, memory, subjectivity, and the passage of life.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: A fantasy novel about the adventures of Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit who embarks on a quest to reclaim the Lonely Mountain and its treasure.

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
description: A novel exploring themes of obsession, revenge, nature, and the human struggle against the elements.

title: The Road
author: Cormac McCarthy
description: A post-apocalyptic novel following a father and son's journey through a desolate landscape, exploring themes of survival, humanity, and hope.

title: The Bell Jar
author: Sylvia Plath
description: A semi-autobiographical novel about a young woman's descent into mental illness, exploring themes of identity, depression, and societal expectations.
